newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Hong Kong broadcaster raps West on "tensions bias".
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong broadcaster raps West on "tensions bias".

text.p: A Hong Kong satellite broadcaster accused Western media on Friday of bias and slanted reporting that gave a distorted image of tensions in the run-up to the territory's handover to China next month.
"Bias has distorted the truth. The Western media is very much to be blamed," said Robert Chua, chairman of China Entertainment Broadcast Ltd (CETV).
"I urge you not to listen to the negative rumours and bad mouthing from some quarters in Hong Kong," Chua said in a speech to the Singapore Confederation of Industries.
"I think Western concerns are not well founded," he said.
But Chua said he thought Sino-British relations had not been damaged by media coverage of the handover so far.
"I cannot speak for the Chinese government, but I think China understands you cannot control the press. I just think they are not pleased with it," he told Reuters after his speech.
Chua said the duty of the media was "to inform the world and give balanced reporting", but he argued this could be done without using television images.
"You can say it, why do you have to show it? You do not change the facts of the news, but you can change the scene. What's the problem?", he said.
Chua, who helped launch Hong Kong's TVB television channel, said criticism from the West that this amounted to news censorship was unfair.
"In my view it's not censorship, it's restraint," he said.
Chua said in his speech there was too much freedom to display graphic images of sex and violence on Western television and was shown "at the expense of society".
"People ask, will it (the media) be free after 1997? Well, you will have your freedom, but you shouldn't abuse it like they do in the West," he said.

Chua, whose CETV is a self-described "no sex, no violence, no news, family-oriented channel", said his station would not cover violence or disturbances if they broke out during coverage of handover celebrations.
"My station is about positive images," he said.
CETV was launched in March 1995 and broadcasts to 33 million homes in China. Chua aims to be in 45 million homes by 1998.
Chua said his mission was "to bring good television to Asia" and added Asian programming was vital to the cultural well-being of the region.
"Too much sex and violence will pollute China and Asian values," he said.

Chua said investment opportunities in Hong Kong would remain exciting and he had "every confidence in the future of Hong Kong" despite concerns the city's economic vibrancy would fade after the handover at midnight on June 30.
